"you would normally associate cold weather for killing bugs etc" Bacteria tend to flourish in warmer, viruses in colder weather. Even stuff like Hep B that comes out in the summer has a gestation period of months and starts in cold weather. Now whether the same will hold for the coronavirus is anyone's guess, but the chances are better than even. Not that the virus will die out - just have greater trouble spreading in the open.As for why the weekends are now locked down for the indefinite future, it's to avoid crowds as the weather improves and people get even tetchier stuck at home. And if they just switch to weekdays, then, well, weekday curfews will come too.

"you would normally associate cold weather for killing bugs etc" Anyone who believes that is just in denial.The virus is thriving in Thailand, for example, and has been for many weeks. To state the obvious, it's miserably hot in Thailand (right now is the hottest part of the year, and even in the not-hottest part of the year, it's incredibly hot...).Expecting the virus to die off during hot weather is just a fantasy.

"Anyone who believes that is just in denial... The virus is thriving in Thailand, for example, and has been for many weeks"Gosh, you're aggressive. And the answer is: look at the data. Though Thailand welcomes millions of Chinese tourists - 11 million in 2019 https://www.thaiwebsites.com/tourism.asp - and has therefore been exposed to the virus from the beginning, the spread has been remarkably slow. It is, after all, a country with a population slightly above the UK's, but with 2,613 cases as opposed to 89,571. Even assuming undercounting - and why? - that's rather better.Edited: 2:12 am, April 14, 2020

Continuing from the above, the reason why the virus should spread less in the summer is two-fold. First, sunlight is a good disinfectant, and dramatically reduces the number of surface viruses exposed to direct sunlight. Second, heat reduces the viability of both droplets and aerosols in the air. Now, it doesn't stop the spread in enclosed spaces, but you're far less likely to catch a virus walking around in the summer than in the winter.You don't hear of flu epidemics in June, do you?Whether the coronavirus will follow the same route is open to question, but, again I say that the chances are better than even. Like the flu, it should retreat. It should also come back in the autumn, but by then I suspect the world will be far better disciplined and prepared, and after this first phase of wringing hands or throwing the kitchen sink at the virus, health officials will have a better idea of what works and what doesn't.Edited: 2:27 am, April 14, 2020

"You chose Thailand as an example, what about other hot countries?"It wasn't me who chose Thailand as an example. I was responding to the claim that Thailand was in the throes of a massive epidemic. If there are other hot countries where the epidemic is raging, I'd like to know, because the only ones that sort of spring to mind are the postage stamps of the Persian Gulf, and I'm not surprised, given living conditions there.Otherwise, it's quite obviously lopsided.I too, base my comments on doctors' comments. It is of course possible that the usual UK summer, even with a heatwave or two, might not be enough, so the doctors we follow and by extension we could be making two different starting assumptions. After all, in July, London apparently has average highs of 22c in the shade, an average of 6 hours of sun a day, and 14 days of rain, while in Istanbul, the numbers are 28c, 12 hours and 3 days.(PS: There was an article I think in the Lancet a short while back that also looked at humidity levels. At very high and very low levels of humidity, the virus may last longer, so it's not just the temperature.)
